stem: A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe, crushing chest pain radiating down his left arm. He is diaphoretic and anxious. His vital signs are: HR 110 bpm, BP 90/60 mmHg, RR 24, SpO2 92% on room air. ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Troponin I is 12 ng/mL (Normal <0.04 ng/mL). Based on this information, identify the most likely causes, the patient's condition, and the appropriate interventions.

rationale.correct: The patient's presentation is highly suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction (MI). The chest pain radiating to the left arm, diaphoresis, and anxiety are classic symptoms. Elevated troponin levels confirm myocardial damage. The ST-segment elevation in inferior leads indicates transmural ischemia, necessitating immediate intervention to restore blood flow and prevent further cardiac damage. Oxygen supports adequate oxygenation of the ischemic myocardium. Aspirin and clopidogrel are antiplatelet agents that inhibit platelet aggregation, preventing further thrombus formation.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect options fail to address the acute nature of the MI or provide treatments that are not immediately indicated. Some options might address secondary issues but do not directly target the underlying cause of myocardial ischemia. Selecting incorrect causes or interventions could lead to delayed or inappropriate treatment, potentially worsening the patient's condition and increasing the risk of complications such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock. Hypovolemia and pulmonary embolism are less likely given the ECG and troponin results. Stable angina is less likely given the acute presentation and elevated troponin. Furosemide and fluid bolus are not indicated at this time.
clinicalPearls: Time is muscle: Rapid identification and intervention are critical in managing acute MI.
ST-segment elevation on ECG is a key indicator of transmural ischemia requiring immediate reperfusion therapy.
Consider contraindications to antiplatelet therapy (e.g., active bleeding) before administration.

questionTrap.trap: Students may focus on individual symptoms without integrating all the clinical data to arrive at the correct diagnosis and treatment.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Encourage students to synthesize all available information, including symptoms, vital signs, ECG findings, and lab results, to make informed decisions.

mnemonic.title: MONA (Modified)
mnemonic.expansion: Oxygen, Aspirin, Nitroglycerin, Morphine (Assess need and contraindications for each)

reviewUnits.title: Acute Coronary Syndrome
reviewUnits.content: Review the pathophysiology, assessment findings, diagnostic criteria, and management of acute myocardial infarction, including STEMI and NSTEMI.

itemContext.sbar: 0800: Patient John Doe, 62-year-old male, presented to the ED with severe chest pain radiating to the left arm. Pain started approximately 30 minutes prior to arrival. Patient is diaphoretic and anxious. 0805: Initial assessment revealed BP 90/60 mmHg, HR 110 bpm, RR 24, SpO2 92% on room air. ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. 0810: Patient reports a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He denies any known allergies other than penicillin. He took aspirin 325mg at home prior to arrival. 0815: Current medications include lisinopril 20mg daily and atorvastatin 40mg daily. Patient is currently on cardiac monitor and receiving oxygen via nasal cannula at 2L/min.

tabs.title: Nurses Notes
tabs.content: 0800: Patient arrived via ambulance reporting 10/10 chest pain radiating to left arm. Diaphoretic and anxious. Vital signs obtained and ECG performed. 0805: Oxygen initiated at 2L/min via nasal cannula. IV access established in right antecubital fossa with 18G catheter. Blood drawn for labs. 0810: Patient reports taking aspirin 325mg prior to arrival. Cardiac monitor attached, showing sinus tachycardia with ST elevation in inferior leads. 0815: Notified physician of patient's condition and orders received. 0820: Administered morphine 4mg IV push for pain. Patient reports slight decrease in pain to 7/10.

tabs.title: Lab Diagnostics
tabs.content: Troponin I: 12 ng/mL (Normal <0.04 ng/mL) | CK-MB: 25 U/L (Normal 0-5 U/L) | Na: 138 mEq/L | K: 4.2 mEq/L | Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL | Glucose: 140 mg/dL

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: HR: 110 bpm | BP: 90/60 mmHg | RR: 24 | SpO2: 92% on room air | Temp: 98.6°F (37°C)

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Lisinopril 20mg PO daily | Atorvastatin 40mg PO daily | Aspirin 325mg PO (self-administered prior to arrival) | Morphine 4mg IV push (0820)

tabs.title: ECG
tabs.content: ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, indicating an inferior wall STEMI.
